questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding a disaster?

choices.text: Occurrence that causes damage to life and property
Occurrence that has the potential to cause disruption or damage to people
Occurrence that causes deterioration of health and health services
Occurrence that can cause substantial economic harm

questions.solution:
A disaster is defined as any occurrence that causes damage, ecological disruption, loss of human life, or deterioration of health and health services. It usually requires an extraordinary response from outside the affected community or area.

A hazard is any phenomenon that has the potential to cause disruption or damage to people and their environment.

questions.text: Which type of natural disaster causes the most deaths?
questions.solution:
Hydrological natural disasters cause the most deaths.

The Disaster Information Management System of Deslnventar classifies natural disasters into five major categories. They are:

  • Geophysical - earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcano eruptions
  • Hydrological - floods, debris flow, and landslides
  • Meteorological - cyclones, tornadoes, extreme temperatures, sandstorms, blizzards etc. 
  • Climatological - drought, forest wildfire, glacial lake outburst etc.
  • Biological - epidemics and insect infestations

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation.

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows:

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about disaster management?

choices.text: Measures to prevent hazards are designed in mitigation phase
Rescue and evacuation occur in recovery phase
Measures on vector control are done in rehabilitation phase
Field care and tagging are done in disaster impact and response phase

questions.solution:
Rescue and evacuation occur in the response phase, not in the recovery phase.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common disease after a disaster?
questions.solution:
Gastroenteritis is the most commonly reported disease after a disaster. 

It occurs due to contamination of water supply, damage to the sewerage system, overcrowding and poor sanitation. Therefore, supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of disease prevention in the post–disaster period.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period?
questions.solution:
Leishmaniasis is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period.

Diseases that are commonly seen in the post-disaster phase are:

  • Gastroenteritis (most common)
  • Acute respiratory infections
  • Leptospirosis
  • Rickettsiosis
  • Rabies
  • Equine encephalitis

questions.text: A district in Andhra Pradesh reported severe drought. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you expect to see in this population?
questions.solution: Vitamin A deficiency is the most common deficiency in areas of famines and droughts. It leads to xerophthalmia and blindness.

questions.text: Following a drought in Bihar, the government launched an immediate mass vaccination program. Which of the following vaccines is recommended in such cases?
questions.solution:
Measles vaccination is recommended for infants and children, immediately following a disaster. This should be given along with vitamin A supplementation as measles can exacerbate vitamin A deficiency.

The vaccination of infants and children against measles is one of the most important public health response measures during a humanitarian crisis when less than 90% of the children or an unknown percentage have already been vaccinated against measles.

Measles and polio vaccines are recommended immediately after an emergency.

Option A: Cholera vaccine is not recommended.

Option B: Hepatitis A vaccine is recommended at the outset of an outbreak.

Option C: Tetanus vaccine is recommended in the early stages and post-emergency stage.

questions.text: Immediately following a disaster, mass vaccination of which of the following vaccines does the WHO recommend?
questions.solution: The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera, and rabies vaccines for mass vaccination after a disaster. However, high-risk populations are recommended to take the cholera vaccine. The rabies vaccine is given only for post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: You are a field doctor at the site of an earthquake. You assist in rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the likelihood of their survival and need for intervention. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
The process of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention is called triage. It is carried out at the site of disaster.

Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.solution:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

An internationally accepted four-color coded system, with red having the highest priority is used commonly here.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?

choices.text: Classifying the victims based on the severity of their injuries and their survival with treatment
Highest preference is given to severely injured patients
More injured victims are given the lowest preference
Color coding is done with red as the highest priority.

questions.solution:
Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.

This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment. It is also done when there is a scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.

The surge capacity of hospitals is increased to accommodate for the natural disaster, by discharging non-emergent existing patients. This enables hospitals to allow for an acute increase in incoming patients.

questions.text: Triage is done during disaster management to ensure treatment of casualties is done properly. What is true about triage done at the disaster site?

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three  color code system

questions.solution:
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority. 

This is because despite paying quite a lot of attention, the benefit is still questionable.

questions.text: What is the level of residual chlorine to be maintained in the water bodies after a disaster?
questions.solution:
The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is 0.7-0.9 mg/L.

Chlorine is a disinfectant that is added to water bodies. In normal conditions, water should have free residual chlorine (FRC) of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/L. However, during a disaster, there is an increased risk of fecal contamination of water sources from the sewage systems. Therefore, it is necessary to increase FRC to 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L.

questions.text: Which of the following gas was responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy?
questions.solution: The gas responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy, which occurred on 3rd December 1984 at the Union Carbide Pesticide Plant, was methyl isocyanate.

questions.text: Which of the following emission occurred in Chernobyl explosion accident of 1986?
questions.solution: Chernobyl nuclear explosion occurred on 26th April, 1986, in the Soviet Union. It caused the release of Iodine-I131, Cesium-Cs134­, Cs137, and Strontium-Sr90, and other isotopes into the atmosphere.

questions.text: What is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India?

choices.text: Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate change

questions.solution:
The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management at the Centre except for dealing with droughts which are under the purview of the Ministry of Agriculture.

Other parts of the Indian government involved in disaster management are the Emergency Medical Relief Wing under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in mitigation of disaster and its preparedness.

questions.text: Which of the following is a nodal centre in case of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The district disaster management authority is the nodal center for disaster management. 

It is chaired by either, the District Collector, District Magistrate or the Deputy Commissioner. The Chief Medical Officer of the district is a part of this authority.

questions.text: The NIDM is involved in the mitigation and management of disasters in India. Who is the president of this institution?
questions.solution:
The National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM) is under the Ministry of Home Affairs of India. Its president is the Union Home Minister.

National Institute of Disaster Management is a premier institute for training and capacity development programs for managing natural disasters in India, on a national as well as regional basis.

questions.text: Who is the chairman of the National Disaster Management Authority of India?

choices.text: Minister of Health and Family Welfare

questions.solution:
National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is an apex body of the Government of India, with a mandate to lay down policies for disaster management. It is chaired by the Prime Minister of India.
